title: 109_hr5091
content: The Act titled "Henry J. Hyde Scholarships for Haiti Act of 2006" is established for a specific purpose. The Act titled "Henry J. Hyde Scholarships for Haiti Act of 2006" establishes an undergraduate scholarship program to bring talented students from Haiti to the US for higher education, aiming to improve educational opportunities, assist Haiti's development, build a well-educated middle-class, and promote positive US-Haiti relationships. Congress finds that providing scholarships to talented students in Haiti to study in the United States will improve educational opportunities, assist in Haiti's development, and strengthen relationships between the US and Haiti. This has been proven to create strong bonds and help developing countries achieve their development goals. In Haiti, talented students from low-income families face limited education opportunities. In 2003, 76% of the population earned less than $2 a day, with 56% earning less than $1 a day. The literacy rate was below 52% for individuals over 15 years old, and the net primary school enrollment rate was 68%. Women in Haiti are disproportionately affected by these challenges. Women in Haiti are disproportionately affected by dire economic and social conditions. Women in Haiti are disproportionately affected by dire economic and social conditions. Authorization of assistance is granted in Section 4. The President will provide scholarships for Haitian citizens and nationals who have excelled in secondary education to study at US institutions. The scholarships will be in the form of a loan, which will be forgiven upon the recipient's return to Haiti to benefit the country. The scholarship program for Haitian citizens studying in the US must include a return to Haiti for at least one year longer than the study period. The program will follow guidelines outlined in the Foreign Relations Authorization Act. Congress believes that the President should provide qualified Peace Corps volunteers to assist Haiti in improving literacy rates and meeting basic needs, promoting mutual understanding between the US and Haiti. Authorization of appropriations is also granted. Authorized appropriations of $2,500,000 for fiscal years 2007-2009 for the President to carry out the Act through the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development. Additional funds are authorized to remain available until expended and are in addition to other available funds. A minimum of $3,000,000 is allocated for literacy and basic education programs under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 for fiscal years 2007-2009, excluding assistance for countries in Latin America and the Caribbean. For fiscal years 2007-2009, $3,000,000 is authorized for literacy and basic education programs in Haiti under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 7. GENERAL AUTHORITIES. The public and private sectors, including the Haitian-American community, are encouraged to contribute to the scholarship program. A matching program may be designed to match contributions. The President shall engage the private sector of Haiti and international private enterprises. The President is encouraged to engage the private sector of Haiti and international enterprises for the development of Haiti through existing scholarship programs like the Cooperative Association of States for Scholarships.
